We understand the value of this data, but investors need to see not just that the current revenue is safe but that new revenue streams and sustainable growth is important and not just from purely from raising prices for the same product. · Another option management could supply would be to supply AI Monthly Active Users and the conversion rate from AI MAU to paid users.

So, why do we have an Outperform? The answer is simply we believe based on our technology background that the moat around the business (and especially the Creative business) is strong and Adobe is innovating fast enough to gain more their fair share of the expanding TAM (and yes we believe there is an expanding TAM created by the democratization of creativity created by AI). We have held numerous calls with creative professionals and users of Adobe (and its leading competitors) creative solutions and have met with management in December (Link) and we believe that while the data is not there to prove out the future we like the technology opportunity. At this price point the reward is far greater than the downside risk to the stock, so we maintain our Outperform rating but can not say how many quarters it will take till it is visible in the numbers.

Salesforce is interesting and controversial. The stock has underperformed over the last year and for many of the same reasons as Adobe - Salesforce has shifted from an AI winner to an AI loser as growth decelerated, management called out how valuable and big their AI offerings would be and this did not materialize in revenue. In fact, Salesforce's management pounded the table more on their AI related offerings (Agentforce and Data Cloud) than Adobe and the sell side jumped on the AI driven acceleration bandwagon (which did not happen or at least not to the same extent with Adobe). Salesforce is also under attack from both AI startups and public companies but the attackers in Salesforce's case are Microsoft and ServiceNow as compared in most cases to much smaller private and a few public entities.

At a high level we believe that Salesforce's core growth problem is that they are predominantly in Cloud saturating (e.g. Sales, Service, analytics, marketing) or Cloud saturated (e.g. collaboration) and while they were hurt (also similar to Adobe) to revenue pull forward during or shortly after the pandemic the fundamental businesses are slowing to the natural growth rate of software (mid to high single digits depending on the ability to take price). AI does make parts of Salesforce's business more easily threatened, especially service as service desks are one of the poster children for Gen AI success but Salesforce does have a strong relationship with their customer and their largest customers own a broad range of Salesforce offerings that are bundled which leads us to believe that Gen AI, at least for the next year or two, will slow growth incremental more than impact overall growth.

The company has countered very aggressively by launching and relaunching their AI offerings which are now mainly called Agentforce and offering data federation and access capabilities via the Data Cloud. They even bought Informatica to expand the reach of their data access capabilities. We believe that Salesforce will have some success with AI in their core businesses, but we do not believe the big dream that Agentforce will be the agentic platform on which enterprises will build Agents beyond core CRM functionality to any meaningful extent. We believe that AI will run where the data resides. This, we believe, limits the upside to countering the negative effects of AI and maybe a bit more over multiple years. Then why an underperform on Salesforce? Our fundamental concern is that the management team is growth centric and when core growth slows they turn to large scale M&A and large, impactful M&A that can accelerate long term growth is expensive and difficult, and we worry that the company will turn in this direction which will negatively impact the stock.

While we agree with Marc Benioff that the fears of AI are overstated we also believe the upside expectations are still too high and worry about an increasing number and size of M&A and the impact that will have on the financials and the fundamentals of the business.

Workday (Q3 earnings) generates its revenue from HCM, Financials and related solutions. This market is still relatively early in its transition to the Cloud (Global Software Primer: Is ERP the next big Cloud transition story?) creating a sustainable growth opportunity. But the uncertain macro environment, which has impacted hiring and thus HCM and large projects combined with the ongoing distraction for IT management from AI have impacted Workday's near-term growth prospects. Workday has also become a show me story as growth has decelerated and while the company has continued to deliver much better than generally expected margins, the focus has been on growth prospects. Interest in the stock, and in-bound call volumes are low as investors are fundamentally concerned growth will continue to decelerate as AI impacts the business.

What is interesting about the concern is that it does not focus as much on enterprises building replacement for HCM or ERP or even competitive pressure per se but on the effect of AI on enterprise hiring and thus Workday's HCM business - something that if it were to occur would have far bigger ramifications than just Workday and which we don't believe will happen in any meaningful investment horizon (Gen AI is a decade / multi-decade story). But even as it relates to Workday, pricing is not predominantly based on seats but rather modules and the size of the customer. This means that any lose of HR personnel does no meaningfully impact Workday revenue. Meanwhile, management delivered preliminary (which they normally beat) FY27 subscription revenue growth guidance of 13% and continued margin improvement and return of cash. The stock is trading at the lowest PEG multiple (Exhibit 3) a ~47% PEG discount to the same time last year (0.7x vs. 1.2x) which we believe is unreasonable given the value of the business.

Snowflake's growth rate has stabilized in CY25, after decelerating massively in the prior four years. From a business perspective, we see this stabilization as a result of multiple factors: · Normalization of Y/Y consumption demand and flush-out of difficult compares from post pandemic demand surge. · Revival in consumption demand · Stabilization of impact from competitive pressure, that had intensified over the last year. · Better than expected results on some newer product initiatives and less than expected negative impact from some headwinds (Iceberg). For additional details, please see our prior note (SNOW 3Q26 review)

As we look forward to CY26, we think that momentum in IaaS/PaaS Consumption demand coupled with potentially lower interest environment should still benefit SNOW. However, last year SNOW also benefited from easier comps, which would no longer be the case this year, and it is difficult to break out exactly how much of the growth stabilization in CY25/FY26 was due to easier comps vs. consumption demand strength. So it is difficult to gain confidence in growth acceleration for CY26/FY27. In balance, valuation on SNOW has climbed down ~25% over the last three months. Therefore, in the near-term, we see next year (FY27) guidance in Feb as an overhang for the stock, and we would recommend staying on the sideline until we get more clarity for next year.

Over the long term, we choose to remain on the side line as we worry about the long-term growth prospects. We think that the core data warehousing market is saturated and decelerating. Driving above-market growth through share gain will get increasingly difficult as competition from existing vendors (database providers, hyperscalers) and newcomers (e.g. Databricks, SaaS app vendors potentially) intensifies.

In addition, we wonder if data warehousing will be as important in a world where more / most important on-premise database moves to the Cloud and every SaaS vendor and hyperscaler offers their own data federation / data Cloud. We acknowledge Snowflake has launched multiple new product initiatives to expand out of the data warehousing market and expand its TAM. We think these newer initiatives are still in early stages and have numerous competitors including the largest Cloud vendors, and we need to see some proof points before assuming meaningful future growth contribution from. We also worry on the AI enthusiasm given how competitive the AI platform market is and fundamentally SNOW is sitting on the 3 largest AI platform vendors (Microsoft, Google, Amazon)

MongoDB is a NoSQL, document-oriented, general-purpose database. It is available both as an on-premise license software and as a cloud-based service on the three large hyperscale cloud platforms (AWS, Azure, and GCP). As a NoSQL / document database, MongoDB affords a more flexible and intuitive data organization, making it easier for developers to work with the database. NoSQL database technology, like MongoDB, offers several advantages like flexibility, ease of use, reliability, and scalability at a lower cost. Furthermore, as MongoDB is available both on-premise and as a cloud-based service, customers can use the MongoDB platform in any environment, depending on their operational requirements: fully managed as a service or selfmanaged in the cloud, on-premise, or a hybrid environment. MongoDB's business model combines the developer mind share and adoption benefits of open-source software with the economic benefits of a proprietary software subscription business model.

Unlike many software companies built around open source projects, MongoDB owns the intellectual property of their core offerings, allowing them to retain control over their products. While MongoDB has capabilities that could, in theory, allow it to one day compete for a broader range of workloads, the company's (and its products') sweet spot is analytics, as the underlying database for applications leverage large volumes of data to support decision-making, drive customer/user experience and IoT (Internet of Things) related applications. The reason we differentiate its sweet spot is that while the product offers capabilities to address a broad range of database use cases, to compete effectively in many of those markets (e.g. transactional databases), MongoDB would (as we wrote last year): · Need better and more functionalities; · Expand the developer ecosystem. Many of these markets are presently dominated by vendors with very powerful capabilities and changing databases is expensive and time-consuming.

This past year the company executed well and this past quarter, they deliver another strong quarter exceeding even our prior optimistic expectations. Overall, with the broader software space struggling with growth stagnation, MDB's stock should continue to benefit from its accelerating growth trajectory. In the near-term, the stock should continue to benefit from: 1) Revival in IaaS/PaaS consumption growth; 2) Increased focus on Enterprise customer; 3) continued strength in new customer addition; and 4) an easing interest rate environment. We also get a sense that under new CEO and CFO, MDB is striving to invigorate growth effort and improve financial visibility to reduce stock volatility. Furthermore, MDB provided positive commentary for FY27 expectations, removing a potential near-term overhang, but upcoming FY27 guidance (in March) could still introduce some volatility.

With the valuation multiple roughly doubling since the recent lows, we think the upside will be primarily driven by healthy 20%+ (est.) top-line growth in CY26/FY27.

We launched on HubSpot in March (Link) and while we liked the business, we did not like the macro overhang, given the company's SMB exposure. We believed at the time there was some downside risk given the stock's valuation multiple and thus launched with a Market-Perform rating. In September, we upgraded the stock (upgrade note) for 4 reasons: 1. Macro issues that concerned us when we launched have abated/stabilized and the downside risks to SMB (HubSpot's core customer) is much lower. 2. The multiple has decreased making the risk / reward trade-off much more favorable. 3. AI is unlikely to be a big downside factor in the foreseeable future and is more likely to be an incremental tailwind to growth for HubSpot as we like the approach taken by management. 4. The setup for H2 is very good and using leading indicators the company is, we believe, likely to beat more than expected.

This past quarter (Link) HubSpot delivered a solid quarter and raised their FY guidance incrementally but the guidance came across as being subdued. Management continues to watch macro conditions given the fact their customers are SMB and therefore more likely to be impacted by any macro issues. Heading into last earnings, we saw two upside drivers for HubSpot: · The potential for beat and raise driving near-term upside, · Strong business fundamental and reset valuation driving long-term upside potential. Given the mixed signal from subdued guidance last quarter despite healthy business metrics, we think near-term upside got pushed out a quarter or two. We see next year (FY26) guidance in Feb as a clarifying event for the stock. Overall, we think business fundamental are intact, and HUBS is well positioned to deliver above market growth over the foreseeable time horizon. Coupled with reset valuation, HUBS provides attractive risk-reward trade-off over longer-time horizon.

The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings: · Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp · Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp · Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp
